G.L. c. 208, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 20, a Probate and Family Court may modify an existing custody or parenting time order upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and that modification serves the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 20, a Probate and Family Court may modify an existing custody or parenting time order upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and that modification serves the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: COMPLAINT FOR MODIFICATION (G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; G.L. c. 215, § 6)

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: Massachusetts courts consistently hold that the primary consideration in any modification proceeding is the best interests of the child. See Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); Albright v. Albright, 425 Mass. 756 (1997).
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: Yannas is a removal/custody case, not a modification proceeding, and it does not speak in terms of modification standards. While it clearly affirms that the “best interests of the child” are the paramount concern in custody and removal decisions, it does not address the specific context of post-judgment modification proceedings. Thus, citing it for the narrower proposition that Massachusetts courts in modification proceedings treat the child’s best interests as the primary consideration is imprecise and overstated.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… a minor child… shall not… be removed out of this commonwealth… unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders. The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child… and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

Albright v. Albright, 425 Mass. 756 (199.proposition: Massachusetts courts consistently hold that the primary consideration in any modification proceeding is the best interests of the child. See Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); Albright v. Albright, 425 Mass. 756 (1997).
Albright v. Albright, 425 Mass. 756 (199.support_reasoning: The opinion in Albright v. Albright is an at‑will employment/public‑policy wrongful discharge case, not a domestic relations or modification proceeding. It does not discuss custody, support, or modification standards, nor does it refer to the “best interests of the child” as the governing standard in any such proceeding. Citing this case for the proposition about Massachusetts modification proceedings and the best interests of the child is therefore inaccurate.
Albright v. Albright, 425 Mass. 756 (199.relevant_excerpt: The judge correctly concluded that the Commonwealth’s broad policies of protecting the family unit and promoting the best interests of children do not transform the discharge of an at-will employee who cannot work particular hours required by her employer into a discharge in violation of a well-defined public policy.

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: A parent’s significant change in residence that affects the practicality and stability of an existing parenting plan constitutes a material change of circumstances. See Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010); Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: This concurrence does not discuss modification of an existing parenting plan or address what constitutes a “material change of circumstances.” Instead, it focuses on statutory interpretation under the paternity statute and holds that a sole legal parent was free to relocate before paternity was adjudicated, and that the judge lacked authority to order her return. The opinion treats relocation here as a given fact to be respected, not as a material change justifying modification of custody or parenting time orders.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: “After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: A parent’s significant change in residence that affects the practicality and stability of an existing parenting plan constitutes a material change of circumstances. See Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010); Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman is a relocation/removal case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, addressing the standard for permitting removal when parents share joint legal and physical custody. The opinion does not discuss “material change of circumstances” as a threshold for modifying an existing parenting plan, nor does it hold that a parent’s residential move, by itself, constitutes a material change. Its focus is on best interests for removal, not on defining what qualifies as a material change warranting modification, so it does not support the specific proposition stated.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002) ... state in pertinent part: “(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances ... only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce] ... (4) ... the court should modify the parenting plan in accordance with the child’s best interests....” [ALI principles are quoted but not adopted as Massachusetts law in this respect.]

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: The Court has wide discretion to modify parenting orders to mitigate excessive travel or disruptions that impair a child’s schooling or well-being. See Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012); Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001).
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses custody determinations, geographic distance between parents, and a parenting schedule, but it does not frame any part of the ruling as a modification of existing parenting orders to reduce excessive travel or school disruption. Instead, the court affirms the initial allocation of primary physical custody and a relatively travel-intensive visitation schedule, noting it provides frequent contact and could be adjusted if Rose returned to Massachusetts. There is no language about exercising broad discretion specifically to change or trim parenting time to mitigate travel burdens or school interference.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “Moreover, the judge stated that, should Rose decide to move back to Massachusetts, the parties must work in good faith to adjust their parenting plan to meet Jill’s best interests.… The judge’s custody order gave Rose frequent contact with Jill, including parenting time one weekend per month in Massachusetts, five weeks in the summer, school vacations, holidays, Web camera sessions three evenings per week, and telephone calls once per week.”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: The Court has wide discretion to modify parenting orders to mitigate excessive travel or disruptions that impair a child’s schooling or well-being. See Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012); Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001).
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on standards for modifying custody (material and substantial change in circumstances) and on removal/relocation under the Yannas ‘real advantage’ framework. It does not discuss modifying parenting orders specifically to reduce excessive travel or to prevent disruptions to a child’s schooling or well-being; if anything, it notes that the existing one-hour travel was accomplished ‘with ease’ and was not an unreasonable burden. Thus, it does not provide authority for broad discretion to modify orders to mitigate travel burdens or school disruption.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “There is nothing in the evidence to suggest that a relocation to Providence, fifty-five miles from Northborough, would preclude the father (whose work schedule was found to be ‘flexible’) from having contact with Caleb in a manner significantly different from that provided by the original divorce judgment. … Transporting Caleb on a weekly basis pursuant to the current visitation schedule was found by the judge to be accomplished ‘with ease,’ and with little burden on the mother.”

Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).proposition: Orders that negatively impact a child’s educational welfare warrant revision under the statutory best-interest standard. See Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).
Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).support_reasoning: The opinion is entirely about modification of alimony obligations upon a payor spouse’s retirement and the retroactive modification of alimony arrears. It does not address child-related issues, educational welfare, or the statutory best-interest-of-the-child standard at all. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that orders negatively impacting a child’s educational welfare warrant revision under a best-interest standard.
Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment.” Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368 (1981). Here, Rudolph was successful in modifying the divorce judgment with respect to his alimony obligation, but he did not succeed in terminating that obligation.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Stability and predictability in a child’s schedule are central considerations in custody determinations. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly emphasizes that stability, continuity, and preservation of a child’s existing arrangements are central to the best-interests analysis in custody cases. The court states that stability is of “enormous benefit” and warns against unnecessary disruption of a child’s living arrangements, treating preservation of the status quo and continuity with caregivers as key considerations. This aligns with the proposition that stability and predictability in a child’s schedule are central in custody determinations.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “It cautions against rearranging a child’s living arrangements in an attempt to achieve some optimum from all the available permutations and combinations of custody and visitation, when it is generally wiser and safer not to meddle in arrangements that are already serving the child’s needs. If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement… Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: Stability and predictability in a child’s schedule are central considerations in custody determinations. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the need for explicit findings about domestic violence and its effects on the child in custody determinations. It does not discuss stability, predictability, or the importance of a stable schedule or routine as central considerations in awarding custody. Any references to the existing or temporary custody arrangements are descriptive, not articulated as a legal principle about stability or predictability being central to the best interests analysis.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: "Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31. We do not by this decision require the judge to hear further testimony if he does not consider that necessary, but at the least he must hear both parties and make explicit findings on the matters set out above."

Cooper v. Cooper, 99 Mass. App. Ct. 486.raw_text: Cooper v. Cooper, 99 Mass. App. Ct. 486 (2021)
Cooper v. Cooper, 99 Mass. App. Ct. 486.proposition: The burden rests on the moving party to demonstrate the material change and corresponding benefit to the child; the Plaintiff herein meets that burden through her factual assertions and supporting evidence. See Cooper v. Cooper, 99 Mass. App. Ct. 486 (2021); White v. LaFlamme, 96 Mass. App. Ct. 764 (2019).

White v. LaFlamme, 96 Mass. App. Ct. 764.raw_text: White v. LaFlamme, 96 Mass. App. Ct. 764 (2019)
White v. LaFlamme, 96 Mass. App. Ct. 764.proposition: The burden rests on the moving party to demonstrate the material change and corresponding benefit to the child; the Plaintiff herein meets that burden through her factual assertions and supporting evidence. See Cooper v. Cooper, 99 Mass. App. Ct. 486 (2021); White v. LaFlamme, 96 Mass. App. Ct. 764 (2019).
